body:
The following three tests fail recently, likely due to recent changes in argument parsing:
```
1/3 Test #358: test/gmtmath/lsfit.sh ............***Failed    0.19 sec
Set GMT_SESSION_NAME = 68820
Error:  [ERROR]: Option -A: Cannot read file !
ERROR: gmtest:90
memtrack errors: 0
exit status: 1

2/3 Test #102: doc/scripts/GMT_hinge.sh .........***Failed    0.31 sec
Set GMT_SESSION_NAME = 68818
Error: r [ERROR]: Unrecognized option -W
ERROR: /home/runner/work/gmt/gmt/build/test/gmtest:90
memtrack errors: 0
exit status: 1

3/3 Test  #47: doc/scripts/GMT_CPTscale.sh ......***Failed    0.33 sec
Set GMT_SESSION_NAME = 68817
Error: r [ERROR]: Unrecognized option -W
ERROR: /home/runner/work/gmt/gmt/build/test/gmtest:90
memtrack errors: 0
exit status: 1
```

comments_content.body:
The two colorbar tests will be fixed by PR #6602.

So the only remaining failing test is `test/gmtmath/lsfit.sh`

```
1/3 Test #358: test/gmtmath/lsfit.sh ............***Failed    0.19 sec
Set GMT_SESSION_NAME = 68820
Error:  [ERROR]: Option -A: Cannot read file !
ERROR: gmtest:90
memtrack errors: 0
exit status: 1
```

I am unable to reproduce that error.  Is this the line ?

`gmt math -A@stepdata.txt+r -N4/1 -C0 1 ADD -C1 T ADD -C2 0.5 STEPT ADD -Ca LSQFIT = solution.txt`

Runs fine for me...

> I am unable to reproduce that error. Is this the line ?
> 
> `gmt math -A@stepdata.txt+r -N4/1 -C0 1 ADD -C1 T ADD -C2 0.5 STEPT ADD -Ca LSQFIT = solution.txt`
> 
> Runs fine for me...

This command with `-Vd` gives me the error:
```
gmtmath [DEBUG]: Look for file /home/user/gmtmath.macros
gmtmath [DEBUG]: Look for file /home/user/.gmt/gmtmath.macros
gmtmath [DEBUG]: Look for file /home/user/.gmt/server/gmtmath.macros
gmtmath [DEBUG]: Look for file /home/user/.gmt/cache/gmtmath.macros
gmtmath [DEBUG]: Could not find file gmtmath.macros
gmtmath [DEBUG]: Look for file stepdata.txt in /home/user/.gmt
gmtmath [DEBUG]: Look for file stepdata.txt in /home/user/.gmt/cache
gmtmath [DEBUG]: Look for file stepdata.txt in /home/user/.gmt/server
gmtmath [ERROR]: Option -A: Cannot read file stepdata.txt!
gmt [DEBUG]: Entering GMT_Destroy_Session
```
and I'm using `6.4.0_5164c30_2022.04.21` on Linux.

Any network issues? I had the file cashed.  I then deleted it and rerunning the command caused it to download from oceania and it worked just fine.  

```
gmtmath [DEBUG]: Get remote file http://oceania.generic-mapping-tools.org/cache/stepdata.txt and write to /Users/pwessel/.gmt/cache/stepdata.txt
gmtmath [DEBUG]: Download http://oceania.generic-mapping-tools.org/cache/stepdata.txt to /Users/pwessel/.gmt/cache/stepdata.txt
gmtmath [INFORMATION]:   -> Download cache file: @stepdata.txt
gmtmath [INFORMATION]: Downloading file http://oceania.generic-mapping-tools.org/cache/stepdata.txt ...
```

I just cleaned up my `~/.gmt` directory and then ran the command again:
```
gmt [DEBUG]: Download remote file http://oceania.generic-mapping-tools.org/gmt_data_server.txt for the first time
gmt [INFORMATION]: Downloading file http://oceania.generic-mapping-tools.org/gmt_data_server.txt ...
gmt [DEBUG]: Delete /tmp/gmt_data_server.txt.download
gmt [DEBUG]: Load contents from /home/seisman/.gmt/server/gmt_data_server.txt
gmt [DEBUG]: Download remote file http://oceania.generic-mapping-tools.org/gmt_hash_server.txt for the first time
gmt [INFORMATION]: Downloading file http://oceania.generic-mapping-tools.org/gmt_hash_server.txt ...
gmt [DEBUG]: Delete /tmp/gmt_hash_server.txt.download
gmt [DEBUG]: Revised options: -A@stepdata.txt+r -N4/1 -C0 1 ADD -C1 T ADD -C2 0.5 STEPT ADD -Ca LSQFIT = solution.txt -Vd
gmtmath [DEBUG]: Look for file /home/seisman/gmtmath.macros
gmtmath [DEBUG]: Look for file /home/seisman/.gmt/gmtmath.macros
gmtmath [DEBUG]: Look for file /home/seisman/.gmt/server/gmtmath.macros
gmtmath [DEBUG]: Look for file /home/seisman/.gmt/cache/gmtmath.macros
gmtmath [DEBUG]: Could not find file gmtmath.macros
gmtmath [DEBUG]: Look for file stepdata.txt in /home/seisman/.gmt
gmtmath [DEBUG]: Look for file stepdata.txt in /home/seisman/.gmt/cache
gmtmath [DEBUG]: Look for file stepdata.txt in /home/seisman/.gmt/server
gmtmath [ERROR]: Option -A: Cannot read file stepdata.txt!
gmt [DEBUG]: Entering GMT_Destroy_Session
```
It successfully downloads the `gmt_data_server.txt` and `gmt_hash_server.txt` files (I checked them. The file contents are correct), but it doesn't try to download `@stepdata.txt`.

If I run `gmt which -Gc @stepdata.txt` to download the file, then the above command works.

Hm, need to think why this is even possible since my gmtmath does indeed initialize the download when needed, so clearly it has the ability.   This is still on macos for you?  And on master of course.
Does the CI handle this test OK?

I'm using Linux.

The test fails on all CI platforms
Thanks, I will step through and see what decisions are made.

These tests pass a few days ago (https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/gmt/runs/6109359722?check_suite_focus=true) but fail yesterday (https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/gmt/runs/6113743767?check_suite_focus=true), because Homebrew just upgraded its Ghostscript from 9.55 to 9.56.1.
Hm, what is the change? Is this a bug in gs or an improvement?

Attached are the test directory for the 4 failing tests:

[gs9561-failures.zip](https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/gmt/files/8582298/gs9561-failures.zip)

OK, just tiny noise related to text.  Not something we did.  Once gs 9.56 starts to appear on macports we might wish to just update the PS.

Perhaps @seisman could make sure that plots using GMT's transparency mechanism still give transparent PDFs etc?

> OK, just tiny noise related to text. Not something we did. Once gs 9.56 starts to appear on macports we might wish to just update the PS.

The problem is, Linux and Windows are slow in upgrading their ghostscript. If we generate the PS files using gs 9.56 on macOS, they may fail on Linux and Windows.
 
> Perhaps @seisman could make sure that plots using GMT's transparency mechanism still give transparent PDFs etc?

Here is the output:
```
$ bash admin/gs_check.sh
Working in build directory
Convert PS_orig_for_gs.ps to PS_orig_for_gs.pdf in order to achieve transparency
Convert PS_orig_for_gs.pdf to PS_orig_for_gs.png
Compare PS_orig_for_gs.png to ../admin/PS_orig_for_gs.png
Image Difference (RootMeanSquaredError):
           Normalized    Absolute
          ============  ==========
     Red: 0.0000000000        0.0
   Green: 0.0000000000        0.0
    Blue: 0.0000000000        0.0
 Opacity: 0.0035425341      232.2
   Total: 0.0017712670      116.1
```
Here is the build directory: [build.zip](https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/gmt/files/8583167/build.zip)

Looks like we are OK.  We may need to do some changes though.  In psconvert, when we are dealing with a PS with transparency, we must first convert that to PDF so that the PS extensions for PDF transparency are applied.  Now, if the final product we want is a raster then we now must convert that PDF to, say, PNG.  This is where 9.56 is different.  Their PDF to * converter is now written in C and not PostScript.   Perhaps we will need to call gpdf down the road but it looks like gs will be happy calling it for us.  Due to different handling of rounding errors they say there may be subtle changes - and I think that is what you see in your failures.

> OK, just tiny noise related to text. Not something we did. Once gs 9.56 starts to appear on macports we might wish to just update the PS.
> 

FYI, macports now provides ghostscript 9.56.1 (https://ports.macports.org/port/ghostscript/details/). So now you can upgrade your ghostscript and update these baseline images.

title: Failing tests due to recent changes
